STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
September 22, 2022
Kathleen Schultz
Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
1715 Sutherland Dr. SE
Kentwood, MI 49508-5072
RE: License #: CB410201260
Investigation #: 2022C0212021
Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
Dear Ms. Schultz:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB410201260
Investigation #: 2022C0212021
Complaint Receipt Date: 07/28/2022
Investigation Initiation Date: 07/28/2022
Report Due Date: 09/26/2022
Licensee Name: Wellspring Lutheran Services
Licensee Address: 4100 Pier N. Blvd Ste. A
Flint, MI 48504
Licensee Telephone #: (989) 262-7386
Administrator: Kathleen Schultz, Administrator
Licensee Designee: Katie Saunders, Designee
Name of Facility: Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
Facility Address: 1715 Sutherland Dr. SE
Kentwood, MI 49508-5072
Facility Telephone #: (616) 281-4601
Original Issuance Date: 12/01/1991
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 06/29/2022
Expiration Date: 06/28/2024
Capacity: Unknown
Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATION
Violation
Established?
Foster Care Worker 1 moved foster youth from placement without No
cause.
There are concerns procedure was not followed and Yes
communication was lacking throughout and following this move.
Additional Findings Yes
FTM was not documented in MiSACWIS and 1105 not provided to Yes
required participates.
DHS-69 Action Summary was not completed as required. Yes
III. METHODOLOGY
07/28/2022 Special Investigation Intake 2022C0212021
07/28/2022 Special Investigation Initiated - On-site visit and interview with LD,
Supervisor, and FCW 2
07/28/2022 Contact - Document Received, Documents reviewed
08/13/2022 Contact - Face to Face, Video conference interviews with agency
staff
08/16/2022 Contact - Face to Face, Video conference interview with staff
08/30/2022 Contact - Telephone call made, Phone call to Foster Parent
09/09/2022 Contact - Document Sent, Email to Foster Parent
09/09/2022 Contact - Document Received, Email with Foster Parent
09/12/2022 Contact - Telephone call made, Phone interview with Foster
Parent
09/12/2022 Contact - Telephone call made, Phone interview with Foster
Parent's adult daughter
09/14/2022 Contact - Document Sent, Email to DHHS worker
09/14/2022 Contact - Face to Face, Reviewed preliminary findings with DCWL
Area Manager
09/16/2022 Contact - Teams interview with DHHS worker
09/16/2022 Contact - Telephone call made. Interview with Respite Person
09/16/2022 Contact - Document sent. Email too LD to provide update.
09/16/2022 Contact - Telephone call made. Interview with Foster Care Worker
1.
09/21/2022 Contact – Face to Face, Video conference pre-exit with LD.
ALLEGATION:
Foster Care Worker 1 moved foster youth from placement without cause.
INVESTIGATION:
On 7/28/22 Foster Parent 1 reported to DCWL that two foster children were removed
from their home before a DHHS investigation was completed. Foster Parent 1 was
told by the agency that the move was temporary. However, the DHHS investigation
is now concluded, and the children have not been returned to the home. In addition,
2

Foster Care Worker 1 did not provide Foster Parent 1 with a DHHS-30 as required at
the time of the move. Foster Care Worker 1 sent the DHHS-30 to Foster Parent 1
approximately two weeks after the move. Foster Parent 1 refused to sign the form as
it indicated Foster Parent 1 asked for the children to be removed, which was untrue.
Foster Parent 1 reported Foster Care Worker 1 then began ignoring her calls and
emails. On 7/20/22, Foster Parent 1 was informed by the agency that Foster Care
Worker 1 was no longer employed.
Licensee Designee (LD)
On 7/28/22 an on-site visit occurred at the agency where Licensee Designee (LD)
was interviewed in person. LD reported Foster Care Worker 1 is no longer with the
agency, as she left employment on 7/15/22. LD reported Child A was hospitalized
on 6/5/22 after being violent and striking out at Foster Parent 1. Child A was not
approved for in-patient care and discharged back to the foster home. Another
incident occurred on 6/6/22 in which Child A was being aggressive and violent. This
incident led to an allegation of improper behavior management and a special
evaluation. After the special evaluation was initiated, Child A was moved to another
home. Foster Parent 1 and 2 had requested the move and the agency agreed it was
in Child A’s best interest at that time. However, Child A’s siblings, Child B & Child C,
remained in the foster home. On 6/22/22 an FTM was held regarding the special
evaluation and findings. DHHS reported it was “more than likely” there would be
findings, which meant Child B and Child C would need to move from the home.
However, DHHS had not yet completed their report. Foster Parent 1 told Foster Care
Worker 1 that she would like Child B and Child C moved. LD was not present at this
meeting and indicated that only Foster Care Worker 1 had direct knowledge of this
request.
On 6/24/22 Licensing Worker contacted Foster Parent 1 and informed her that a
placement was found. Replacement occurred on 6/27/2022. A few days later the
agency was informed that DHHS was not going to have findings after all. However,
there were charges pending with law enforcement. At that time, the agency
anticipated their special evaluation would have licensing violations regarding
behavior management. Because of the licensing findings and possible criminal
charges, returning the children to the foster home was not considered.
On 7/18/22 Foster Parent 1 emailed Foster Care Supervisor 1 and asked to have the
children returned to her home. On 7/21/22 Foster Care Supervisor 1 notified Foster
Parent 1 that Foster Care Worker 1 was no longer with the agency and a new
supervisor was assigned. Foster Care Supervisor 1 also informed Foster Parent 1
that there were no plans to move the children back to the foster home at that time.
On 7/27/22 an internal meeting occurred, where it was discussed that Licensing
Worker would contact the foster parents and update them on the special evaluation
findings. On 7/28/22 the new worker, Foster Care Worker 2, replied to an email from
Foster Parent 1, and explained the agency would not be moving the youth back to
the foster home at that time. The worker explained that reunification was in process
and the children’s new placement was within the school district where their parent’s
3

live, which would help with transitioning the youth home when reunification occurred.
The new foster home was close to the parent’s home, which also helped with
visitation. For those reasons, the agency felt another placement change was
unnecessary for Child B and Child C. The agency was hopeful the kids next move
would be their return home.
LD forwarded the emails that were discussed during the interview. The emails
verified the information provided by the LD.
Licensing Worker
On 8/13/22 an interview was conducted with Licensing Worker via Teams. Licensing
Worker was unavailable on the day of the site visit. Licensing Worker reported she
was the assigned worker for the foster home and completed the recent special
evaluation. Licensing Worker stated DHHS Worker anticipated they would have
findings in the investigation which would require Child B and Child C to move from
the home. However, the agency did not want to move the kids until they knew for
sure and had the DHHS report. A family team meeting (FTM) occurred on
Wednesday 6/22/22, with DHHS, the foster parents, Foster Care Worker 1, and
Licensing Worker to discuss the likely outcome of the investigation. Foster Parent 1
was very upset. Foster Parent 2 discussed moving out of the home, to allow Child B
and Child C to remain there. The foster parents were encouraged to take some time
to think about things. However, Foster Parent 1 said if the move was inevitable
because of the DHHS findings, they would rather have the kids move sooner than
later. Licensing Worker told the foster parents the agency was still waiting for the
final word from DHHS and the foster parents should take the weekend to talk things
over. The following day, Foster Parent 1 called Licensing Worker and said she
wanted to have Child B and Child C moved. Foster Parent 1 expressed she wanted
the kids moved before 1:00 Monday (6/27/22) as Foster Parent 2 would be at work,
and the kids move would be too hard on him. Licensing Worker contacted Foster
Parent 1 again that Friday (6/24/22) to confirm the move, as she though the foster
parent may have second thoughts. However, Foster Parent 1 agreed to contact the
new foster parent to provide information and make arrangements for the move. The
kids then moved Monday, 6/27/22.
After the move occurred, Foster Parent 1 told Licensing Worker that she wished to
provide permanence to the kids if reunification did not occur. However, prior
conversations with Foster Parent 1 never included discussion of the move being
temporary or the kids moving back to the home.
About two weeks after the move, the agency was informed DHHS did not have
findings in their investigation. After the foster parents were informed of this
information by DHHS, Foster Parent 1 called Licensing Worker and wanted to
discuss when Child B and Child C could return to the home. The agency then had an
internal meeting to discuss the situation. It was determined the children would stay in
their new placement, as they were close to reunification and living in their parent’s
community. Foster Parent 1 was frustrated by this decision.
4

Foster Care Worker 2 (FCW2)
An interview was conducted via Teams on 8/13/22. Foster Care Worker 2 (FCW2)
was assigned to the children’s case in July 2022. FCW 2 reported being new to the
case as of 7/7/22. FCW2 was not present for the TDM or other phone calls. FCW2
reviewed the case file and did not recall seeing any documentation about Child B
and Child C’s removal being a temporary situation.
Foster Care Supervisor 1
An interview was conducted via Teams on 8/16/22. Supervisor recalled that Foster
Care Worker 1 and Licensing Worker had the most contact with the foster parents.
Both staff reported Foster Parent 1 said she wanted Child B and Child C to be
moved, because it seemed inevitable, and they were about to have family visiting
the home for an extended period of time. Supervisor did not attend the 6/22/22 FTM
and she was on vacation when the move occurred on 6/27/22.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 recalled the foster parents were upset that they did not
receive the DHS-30 at the time of the move. When Foster Care Worker 1 later
provided it, the foster parents refused to sign it, because it was not given to them
timely. Foster Care Supervisor 1 had a meeting with the foster parents on 8/4/22 to
discuss their concerns. The foster parents were informed of the agency’s decision to
leave the children in their current placement. The foster parents seemed to
understand that decision and did not pursue the issue further.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 stated she was unaware of any plans for the children’s
move to be temporary. However, there may have been some misunderstanding
between the foster parents and worker. The new placement was intended to be
short term, only because reunification with the children’s parents was expected to
occur shortly after.
Foster Parent 1 (Complainant)
On 9/12/22 a phone interview occurred with Foster Parent 1 (FP1). FP1 stated Child
B and Child C never should have been removed from the home. FP1 reported after
the DHHS investigation interviews occurred, a Family Team Meeting (FTM) was held
on 6/22/22 to discuss the findings. During the meeting it was discussed that if there
were not findings, the children (Child B & C) could stay in the home. If there were
DHHS findings, the children would need to be moved. At that time, Child A had
already been moved from the home. During the meeting, the DHHS Worker
indicated she would be off over the July 4th holiday, therefore a decision would not
be made until after that time. FP1 reported they had family coming to visit over the
holiday as well and asked the agency if they should move the children. The agency
responded that a decision did not need to be made at that time, and they would wait
until after DHHS findings were known. Everyone was in agreement to maintain the
placement until DHHS concluded their investigation. After the FTM, Foster Care
5

Worker 1 contacted FP1 twice, asking if they needed respite. FP1 declined the offer
for respite. On 6/24/22 Licensing Worker informed FP1 that a new placement was
located for Child B & C. Licensing Worker stated the move was arranged as the
outcome of the investigation was known and DHHS had findings which did not allow
the children to stay in the home. Licensing Worker indicated the move may be
temporary until the investigation was complete. FP1 told Licensing Worker that if the
agency planned to move the children, they should do it while her husband was at
work, because he would be upset. It was agreed the children would move on
6/27/22. At the time of the move, Child B and C were upset, and FP1 reassured
them the move was only temporary. FP1 recalled a later conversation with the new
foster parent in which they stated the move was intended to be permanent all along.
On 7/11/22 DHHS worker told FP1 there were no findings from the investigation.
FP1 contacted FCW1 to request a meeting to discuss findings and a plan to
transition the children back to the home. FP1 stated she made several attempts to
contact FCW1, with no response. On 7/19/22 the agency informed her that FCW1
was no longer employed there, and a new worker was assigned (FCW2). FCW2
contacted FP1 on 7/28/22 to discuss the situation and schedule a meeting. At the
meeting on 8/4/22, the agency stated they were not going to move the children back
to FP1’s home. The agency said the children were settled at the new home and had
begun receiving required services. The agency also informed FP1 that DHHS initially
stated there would be findings in the investigation, which is what caused the move.
However, after the children were moved, DHHS reported there would not be
findings. FP1 indicated she did not believe this was true, as she spoke with DHHS
Worker and was never told this information.
Foster Parent’s Daughter
On 9/12/22 a brief phone interview was conducted with the adult daughter of the
foster parents. She reported being present during the 6/22/22 FTM call as a support
person for her parents. During the call, there was no decision to move the children
from the home; neither foster parents requested the children to be moved.
Respite Worker
On 9/16/22 a phone interview was conducted with someone identified as a respite
care provider for the foster family. Respite Worker reported being present for the
6/22/22 FTM call as a support person to the foster family. Respite Worker stated
during the call DHHS Worker indicated she was unsure what the findings would be.
A plan was not developed during that call to move the kids. However, FP1 did state
that if the decision was made to move the kids, the agency should do it before they
had family visiting over the 4th of July holiday.
DHHS
On 9/16/22 a Teams interview was conducted with DHHS worker. The information
provided by DHHS worker was consistent with agency staff. DHHS worker stated at
the time of the 6/22/22 FTM, it appeared there was enough information to have
findings that would result in the removal of Child B and C. At the FTM, the agency
6

and foster parent were encouraged not to make any decision until the report was
finalized as DHHS worker needed to confirm the findings with supervision. However,
FP1 stated she would rather move the youth before the holiday, because they
planned to have family visiting and did not want to deal with the investigation and
kids being moved while family was visiting. However, Licensing Worker encouraged
FP1 to take time to think about it. According to the agency, FP1 called the day after
the meeting and asked to have the kids moved. Overall, DHHS worker indicated
there was a disconnect between the agency and FP1, resulting in trust issues and
miscommunication. DHHS worker could tell there was tension with FCW1 and FP1
which may have contributed to a lack of clarity about the agency’s decision.
Foster Care Worker 1
A phone interview was conducted on 9/16/22 with FCW1. FCW1 reported that she
left employment with the agency in early July 2022. FCW1 stated that after an
incident with Child A acting out violently, and an allegation of improper physical
discipline by the foster parents, a special evaluation was initiated. Child A had been
removed from the home due to the special evaluation and also at the request of the
foster parents. There was some discussion about keeping the siblings placed
together. However, before a determination could be made about placement for all
three children, DHHS reported there would be findings with the investigation and
Child B and C would need to be moved. A meeting occurred on 6/22/22 in which the
foster parents were informed of the situation. A replacement decision was not made
at that time. However, FP1 later called Licensing Worker and stated they had family
coming to stay over the holiday weekend, and the kids should be moved before
then. The kids were then moved to a new placement on 6/27/22. The new foster
home was in an area near their parents and the school the kids would continue to
attend once reunification occurred. A few weeks after the kids moved, DHHS
reported there would not be any findings after all.
FCW1 stated she did not recall ever telling FP1 that the move was temporary. When
FCW1 picked up the children to move them on 6/27/22, FP1 had all of the children’s
belongings packed. Which made it appear she understood the move was
permanent. If the move were intended to be short-term, it seems FP1 would have
only packed a suitcase.
Document review
On 7/28/22 the children’s case file was reviewed. The following relevant information
was found:
 Child A, B and C were placed with Foster Parent 1 on 4/9/21. Child A moved
on 6/7/22, Child B and C moved on 6/27/22.
 A Special Evaluation was initiated on 6/7/22. The special evaluation was
conducted in coordination with DHHS. It was alleged Foster Parent 2 used
inappropriate behavior management with Child A. It was reported Foster
Parent 2 grabbed Child A’s arm, leaving a bruise, and hit his nose with his
finger. Foster Parent 1 reported the incident began when Child A was acting
out violently toward her and also injuring himself. Foster Parent 1 reported
7

that Foster Parent 2 put his hands on Child A’s shoulders and pointed his
finger at Child A, accidentally hitting his nose. Foster Parent 2 confirmed
Foster Parent 1’s account of events. The DHHS investigation closed on
7/18/22, with no findings. The agency special evaluation closed on 9/7/22 with
a behavior management violation. A CAP was developed to bring the home
into compliance.
 The foster home had one prior special evaluation regarding behavior
management in April 2022. No violation was found.
 DHHS investigation report noted an FTM occurred on 6/22/22 to discuss
investigation findings. At that time, there appeared to be enough evidence to
support findings. However, it was later determined there would not be any
findings. This information was shared with the family on 7/11/22.
 6/22/22 FTM documentation from DHHS showed the following people in
attendance: FP1, FP2, Foster Parent’s Daughter, Respite Worker, DHHS
Worker, Licensing Worker. Participants discussed likely outcome of
investigation and findings, and what that meant regarding placement. Per
report, “pending supervisory approval, this will be a substantiated case”. FP1
suggested, “changing placement sooner than later since it seems inevitable,
and they’ll have family visiting the next two weeks”. “Licensing Worker and
FP1 will touch base Friday 6/24 to discuss placement”.
 Emails, from 7/19/22 and 7/28/22, between Foster Parent 1 and Foster Care
Worker 2 were observed. In the emails, FCW2 explained the reasons why the
children would not be returned to Foster Parent 1’s home. Foster Parent 1
maintained she believe the removal was temporary.
 Email from FCW 2 to Foster Parent 1, providing the agency’s grievance
policy.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-03D Placement Change
Page 2
When a caseworker suspects a child in foster care has suffered
sexual abuse or non-accidental physical injury, or there is a
substantial risk of harm to the child's emotional well-being or
physical safety in the caregiver's home, a CPS complaint and a
licensing complaint must be made immediately.
Additionally:
• If the caseworker believes the child is at substantial risk in the
home, then child must be moved immediately. If the child is
moved due to the allegations, the caregiver may appeal the
decision to the Foster Care Review Board (FCRB). The appeal
does not prevent the move…
8

ANALYSIS: Based on interviews and documents reviewed, it was
determined the agency made a placement decision based on
the information they had at the time, that DHHS had findings in
their investigation. The agency’s placement decision is in
alignment with contract/policy item FOM 722-03D. Therefore, no
violation is found.
Regarding Foster Parent’s assertion the agency initially reported
the move to be temporary, then made the move permanent
without discussing it, no violation is found. There was conflicting
information reported by the Foster Parent, support persons,
agency staff, and DHHS regarding the plan for the children’s
move. In addition, policy does not prohibit staff from moving
youth on a temporary basis, then changing the placement to a
permanent one if the placement meets the children’s needs.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
There are concerns procedure was not followed and communication was lacking
throughout and following this.
INVESTIGATION:
During a review of MiSACWIS documents relevant to this investigation, it was found
that a DHS-30, Foster Parent/Caregiver Notification of Move, was not uploaded into
MiSACWIS.
Interviews with Foster Parent 1, Licensee Designee, and Foster Care Worker 1
confirmed the DHS-30 was not completed or provided to the foster parent as
required.
Email documentation was reviewed and verified Foster Care Worker 1 sent the
DHS-30 to Foster Parent 1 via email on 7/14/22; 17 days after the replacement
occurred. Foster Parent 1 refused to sign the document as it was not provided
timely.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-03D Placement Change
Page 4
The caregiver must be notified of the intent to move the child 14
days prior to the intended date of the move unless the child’s
health or safety is jeopardized. The DHS-30, Foster
Parent/Caregiver Notification of Move, must be used to notify
the caregiver of the intent to move the child. The DHS-30
contains information for the caregiver regarding whether the
right to appeal the placement change exists based on the
placement change reason and instructions for exercising their
9

right to appeal; see Caregiver Appeal to the Foster Care Review
Board in this item. The DHS-30 must be uploaded to MiSACWIS
in the document hyperlink in the child's placement record.
ANALYSIS: Based on interviews and a review of the MiSACWIS case
record, it was determined the agency did not provide the DHS-
30 to the foster parents at the time of the move. A DHS-30 was
not signed by the caregiver or uploaded into the system.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
FTM was not documented in MiSACWIS and 1105 not provided to required
participates.
INVESTIGATION:
During a review of MiSACWIS documents relevant to this investigation, it was found
that the 6/22/22 FTM was not documents in the system. It was also determined that
an 1105 document was not generated or provided to the FTM participants.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Page 17
Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for the
following:
• Completing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
checking it for accuracy, identifying areas needing follow-up,
and recording the outcome data.
• Providing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, to all
participants (in person and by phone), legal parents, and
casework supervisor. These documents must also be uploaded
into the electronic case management record.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in the
electronic case management record using the FTM hyperlink
within seven business days of the FTM.
ANALYSIS: Upon review of documents in MiSACWIS it was determined the
requirements of this policy were not followed.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/10/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/28/2021
6/7/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/28/2022
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
DHS-69 Action Summary was not completed as required.
INVESTIGATION:
During a review of MiSACWIS documents relevant to this investigation, it was found
that the DHS-69 Action Summary was not completed as required for the children’s
10

move. The children’s placement changed on 6/27/22. A DHHS-69 was not
completed until 7/12/22.
During an interview with FCW1, it was reported the DHHS-69 was completed prior to
leaving employment. However, it was completed after the due date.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
Page 3
Three days prior to a planned placement change, or within three
business days of an emergency placement change, the
caseworker must document…
ANALYSIS: Upon review of the MiSACWIS case record it was determined a
DHHS-69 Action Summary was not completed within the
required timeframe.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/10/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/28/2021
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable CAP, I recommend no change in the license status.
_ ______________September 21, 2022____________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 22, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
11
